job_title: Registered Nurse in Grand Forks, ND

job_title: Registered Nurse in Devils Lake, ND
pros: Good hours, 3 twelve hour shifts a week
cons: Current management creates an uncomfortable work environment by ignoring the concerns of many of their nurses regarding improper practices occurring in the unit and unfair treatment of their own employees. Current management treats each employee differently based off of their personal opinion of that individual, rather than focusing on the quality of the care the nurse is providing to their patients. This is unfair to the employees as it creates unclear expectations of the standard procedures each nurse is expected to follow when providing care for their patients. This is detrimental to the quality of care the patients are receiving. Each nurse is being held to a different standard based off of the personal opinion of their superior, which leads to inconsistencies in how patients are treated depending on the nurse. These concerns have been brought to the supervisor's attention by multiple nurses on multiple occasions, yet they continue to be ignored and the issues continue to persist.

job_title: Medical Technologist in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Great natural views. Close to the park and river. You always have a place can enjoy the peace. Relax from work. Parking is relatively easy.
cons:
1. Diversity not friendly. 
When you are minority races, you will be treated different way. I am an Asian, so I feel like my coworker kept reporting and complaining me to the manager, whatever she thinks that can hurt me. Even some mistakes other coworkers could make, she would ignore it. Only focus on me. 

2/Bad management. Too political working environment. 
From HR to your manager, nobody will speak for you. They just listen to their old employees feedback. They never known what's going on in the real clinic work. HR building is a mile away from main hospital, and manager office is in the separate building. Who cares you are right or wrong. They just listen to those old workers, maybe they can keep hospital making money from the patients. If you're a new worker and get bullied by others, I'm sorry you can do nothing here. 

My feeling of working here is just like I was running for the President of America. You can't pay my attention on my job, Although there is something needs to be improved, lots of things distract you from getting growth. In stead, I have to deal with my coworkers bad mouth on me. 

3/Coworkers talking all the time. 
My coworker was talking about me all the time, but I can do nothing with it. because I am new here. I deserve getting this. Drama.

I'm kind of new to this job. I've never seen this employer before. They will count 'mistakes' you had before, doesn't matter they're correct or wrong, doesn't matter you did before or already improved, They don't care. They only know, there is other new here, you can leave now.

review_title: Great company with solid values and friendly staff!
job_title: Manager in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
Focus on providing world class health care to our patients

Compassionate values

Competitive pay & benefits

Very friendly & competent staff with high tenure and low turnover

Strong focus on employee & management development

Investing in the future of the company and staff by partnering with world-class companies such as: Mayo, Virginia Mason, Studer Group, & Huron Healthcare.
cons:
Little competition in Grand Forks reduces the sense of urgency to change to meet future demands in the healthcare industry.  Actions seem to be reactive instead of proactive; however this culture is in the process of changing.

Long tenured employees sometimes lack awareness of best practices from broader healthcare industry, which is now being addressed by outside consulting companies such as Mayo, Studer Group, Huron Healthcare, & Virginia Mason.

The Midwest culture of nice hinders direct conflict resolution and creates unnecessary undercurrents of unresolved personality differences.  

The physician practices are owned by the health system, but physicians are treated like owners of the organization rather than employees.

review_title: Good place to work in Grand Forks
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Forks, ND
pros: competitive pay, good core values
cons: old and outdated, lack of communication, very grumpy nursing staff (awful to work with)

review_title: Best place to work in Grand Forks
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Forks, ND
pros: I've had the privilege of working at Altru for over 30 years.  This company is very progressive:  always staying at the forefront of new technology and innovative ideas, all of which will benefit patient and employee.  Patient and staff rounding by leaders has helped bridge connections in both areas.  It's nice to know that our leaders are taking the time to allow us to express ourselves, and that they truly follow-up on what we've said.
cons: Hopefully, one day, the cafeteria will be able to be moved out of the basement, and onto an upper level with windows. It would be nice if they could have the luxury to expand.  The scramble area at lunch time can be quite crowded. The new paint and furnishings there are beautiful ... it's helped to make it more open.

job_title: CNA in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
Working with really awesome patients
Good hands on experience in the medical field
cons:
When I first started working here, I really enjoyed it, But management has become disastrous. They do not care about their staff. Always short staffed, no pay raises or ability to progress. Overworked! Unappreciated and managers don’t listen to feedback.

They’re all about making money, even if it means having 1 staff member caring for way too many patients.. resulting in poor care. Managers get bonuses for being short staffed and pocket it for themselves. 

You’re frequently  floated off your own unit to sit 1:1 with patients.

I’d say go somewhere else, but it’s tough when they’re the ruling medical facility in grand forks.

review_title: No support from management and no trust between workers.
job_title: Patient Access in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
Lots of open positions at all times and the ability to advance.  
Advancement is typically from within. 
There are education classes available. 
Many locations within the region so there are options to move to the other locations.
Yearly evaluations with raises. 
Paid time off accrues quickly.
cons:
No support from supervisors and there is never two sides to any story. 
Vacation approval is on a seniority basis so you are heavily restricted on the time you can take off. 
Supervisors are not on the floor so they are out of touch of the day to day problems.

review_title: Altru is a great health system to work for. You aren't just another employee, you are part of a team making a difference
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
- Involvement in change
 - Make a difference in people's lives 
 - Excellent internal corporate communication
 - Senior leadership is present with staff. They aren't just some taking heads.
 - Even younger staff are listened to. Everyone's view matters.
cons: Sometimes there are too many bureaucratic barriers to staff accomplishing a specific task. Or managers aren't sometimes present in the moment and miss important information that needs to be communicated to staff about organizational change.

review_title: Not worth the sign on bonus

review_title: Love my coworkers, but staffing ratios unsafe
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Grand Forks, ND
pros:
-Coworkers are great
- Patient population is for the most part grateful and appreciative of your services
- Pay is pretty good
cons:
-Emphasis is put on patient numbers rather than patient and staff safety
-Little to no competition in area makes it feel like management has more leverage than employees and are less willing to make changes to increase staff satisfaction
-Patient ratios are the most dangerous I have seen in my 7 year career and in multiple states

review_title: Better than any of the 3 other hospitals where I have worked!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Grand Forks, MN
pros: Teamwork, co-operation, mutual respect, leadership, honesty, willingness of leaders to be the first to make sacrifices and be examples for the rest of employees.
cons: Poor communication from Human Resources about on-going needs for maintaining health benefits.  Required flu vaccination for all employees no communicated until after hired.  No exceptions to flu shot requirement.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Many options for RN's, they promote from within, management cares for employees, all staff are treated as equals and valuable assets (from doctors to housekeeping), great team work, genuinely nice people, egalitarian culture, 4-5% yearly raises, generous PTO, supportive coworkers, nice patient population.
cons: Working short staffed at times. But team work and excellent comradery make it tolerable, compensation is fair but could be better.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Grand Forks, ND

job_title: Registered Nurse in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Selfless, hardworking coworkers and competitive compensation.
cons: Unsafe staffing ratios. Upper management is overbearing and uninterested in hearing input from bedside staff. No raises or bonuses due to hospital losing money. They allow physicians to verbally abuse nursing staff. Structurally, the hospital is (literally) falling apart. Hospital staff have to park far away (20 minute walk) while administration gets to park right next to the hospital. The cafeteria closes at 7pm.  The health insurance through Altru is a joke.

job_title: Staff RN in Grand Forks, ND
pros: Altru has a great staff and many who have been on staff for years but help bring up new nurses and foster team work. It's the best place I've worked.
cons: Staffing can sometimes be an issue but they hire travel nurses when necessary and current management is taking staffing seriously and looking for solutions.
